column8: failed to represent him adequately

column10: respondent alleged that Shepard's actions violated certain of his constitutional rights.  To establish that Shepard acted ""under color of state law

column1: 1. A public defender does not act ""under color of state law"" when performing a lawyer's traditional functions as counsel to an indigent defendant in a state criminal proceeding.  Because it was based on such activities
column2: the complaint against Shepard must be dismissed.  Pp.  454 U. S. 317-325.

column1: (a) From the moment of Shepard's assignment to represent respondent
column2: their relationship became identical to that existing between any other lawyer and client
column3: except for the source of Shepard's payment.  The legal system posits that a defense lawyer best serves the public not by acting on the State's behalf or in concert with it
column4: but rather by advancing the undivided interests of the client.  This is essentially a private function for which state office and authority are not needed.  Pp.  454 U. S. 317-319.

column1: (b) Cases in which this Court assumed that state-employed doctors serving in supervisory capacities at state institutions could be held liable under  1983 are not controlling.  O'Connor v. Donaldson

column1: (c) Although the employment relationship between the State and a public defender is a relevant factor
column2: it is insufficient to establish that a

column1: public defender acts under color of state law within the meaning of  1983.  A public defender is not amenable to administrative direction in the same sense as other state employees.  And equally important

column1: 1. The Court of Appeals erred when
column2: without first determining whether an inconsistent verdict would be unconstitutional
column3: it directed the state trial judge to provide an explanation of the apparent inconsistency in his verdicts.  Federal judges have no general supervisory power over state trial judges
column4: and may not require the observance of any special procedures except when necessary to assure compliance with the dictates of the Federal Constitution.

column1: 2. An apparent inconsistency in a trial judge's verdict does not give rise to an inference of irregularity in his finding of guilt that is sufficiently strong to overcome the well established presumption that the judge adhered to basic rules of procedure.  Here
column2: even assuming that the codefendant's acquittal was logically inconsistent with respondent's conviction
column3: respondent
column4: who was found guilty beyond a reasonable doubt after a fair trial
column5: has no constitutional ground to complain that his codefendant was acquitted.

column3: instituted wrongful death litigation in a California state court against petitioners
column4: which are the company that manufactured the plane in Pennsylvania and the company that manufactured the plane's propellers in Ohio.  At the time of the crash
column5: the plane was registered in Great Britain and was owned and operated by companies organized in the United Kingdom.  The pilot and all of the decedents' heirs and next of kin were Scottish subjects and citizens
column6: and the investigation of the accident was conducted by British authorities.  Respondent sought to recover from petitioners on the basis of negligence or strict liability (not recognized by Scottish law)
column7: and admitted that the action was filed in the United States because its laws regarding liability
column8: capacity to sue
column9: and damages are more favorable to respondent's position than those of Scotland.  On petitioners' motion
column10: the action was removed to a Federal District Court in California and was then transferred to the United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania
column11: pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  1404(a).  The District Court granted petitioners' motion to dismiss the action on the ground offorum non conveniens.  Relying on the test set forth in Gulf Oil Corp. v. Gilbert
column13: and analyzing the ""private interest factors"" affecting the litigants' convenience and the ""public interest factors"" affecting the forum's convenience
column15: the District Court concluded that Scotland was the appropriate forum.  However
column17: holding that the District Court had abused its discretion in conducting the Gilbert analysis and that

column1: the law of the alternative forum is less favorable to the plaintiff than the law of the forum chosen by the plaintiff.

1. Plaintiffs may not defeat a motion to dismiss on the ground of forum non conveniens merely by showing that the substantive law that would be applied in the alternative forum is less favorable to the plaintiffs than that of the chosen forum.  The possibility of a change in substantive law should ordinarily not be given conclusive or even substantial weight in the forum non conveniens inquiry.  Canada Malting Co. v. Paterson Steamships
column2: Ltd.
supra
column3: dismissal will ordinarily be appropriate where trial in the plaintiff's chosen forum imposes a heavy burden on the defendant or the court
column4: and where the plaintiff is unable to offer any specific reasons of convenience supporting his choice.  If substantial weight were given to the possibility of an unfavorable change in law
column5: however
column6: dismissal might be barred even where trial in the chosen forum was plainly inconvenient
column7: and the forum non conveniens doctrine would become virtually useless.  Such an approach not only would be inconsistent with the purpose of the forum non conveniens doctrine
column8: but also would pose substantial practical problems
column9: requiring that trial courts determine complex problems in conflict of laws and comparative law
column10: and increasing the flow into American courts of litigation by foreign plaintiffs against American manufacturers.  Pp.  454 U. S. 248-252.

column1: (b) Nor may an analogy be drawn between forum non conveniens dismissals and transfers between federal courts pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  1404(a)
column2: which was construed in Van Dusen v. Barrack
column4: as precluding a transfer if it resulted in a change in the applicable law.  The statute was enacted to permit change of venue between federal courts
column5: and although it was drafted in accordance with the doctrine of forum non conveniens
column6: it was intended to be a revision
column7: rather than a codification of the common law.  District courts were given more discretion to transfer under  1404(a) than they had to dismiss on grounds of forum non conveniens. Van Dusen v. Barrack
column8: supra

column1: 2. The District Court properly decided that the presumption in favor of the plaintiff's forum choice applied with less than maximum force when the plaintiff or (as here) the real parties in interest are foreign.  When the plaintiff has chosen the home forum
column2: it is reasonable to assume that the choice is convenient; but when the plaintiff or real parties in interest are foreign
column3: this assumption is much less reasonable
column4: and the plaintiff's choice deserves less deference.  Pp.  454 U. S. 255-256.

column1: 3. The forum non conveniens determination is committed to the trial court's sound discretion
column2: and may be reversed only when there has been a clear abuse of discretion.  Here
column3: the District Court did not abuse its discretion in weighing the private and public interests under the Gilbert analysis
column4: and thereby determining that the trial should be held in Scotland.  Pp.  454 U. S. 257-261.

column1: (a) In analyzing the private interest factors
column2: the District Court did not act unreasonably in concluding that fewer evidentiary problems would be posed if the trial were held in Scotland
column3: a large proportion of the relevant evidence being located there.  The District Court also correctly concluded that the problems posed by the petitioners' inability to implead potential Scottish third-party defendants -- the pilot's estate
column5: and the charter company -- supported holding the trial in Scotland.  Pp.  454 U. S. 257-259.

column1: (b) The District Court's review of the factors relating to the public interest was also reasonable.  Even aside from the question whether Scottish law might be applicable in part
column2: all other public interest factors favor trial in Scotland
column3: which has a very strong interest in this litigation.  The accident occurred there
column4: all of the decedents were Scottish
column5: and apart from petitioners
column6: all potential parties are either Scottish or English.  As to respondent's argument that American citizens have an interest in ensuring that American manufacturers are deterred from producing defective products and that additional deterrence might be obtained by trial in the United States where they could be sued on the basis of both negligence and strict liability
column7: any incremental deterrence from trial in an American court is likely to be insignificant and is not sufficient to justify the enormous commitment of judicial time and resources that would be required.  Pp.  454 U. S. 259-261.

column2: a state university
column3: makes its facilities generally available for the activities of registered student groups. Members of the group then brought suit in Federal District Court
column5: inter alia
column6: their rights to free exercise of religion and freedom of speech under the First Amendment.  The District Court upheld the regulation as being not only justified
column7: but required
column8: by the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column9: viewing the regulation as a content-based discrimination against religious speech
column10: for which it could find no compelling justification
column11: and holding that the Establishment Clause does not bar a policy of equal access
column12: in which facilities are open to groups and speakers of all kinds.

column1: Held:  The University's exclusionary policy violates the fundamental principle that a state regulation of speech should be content-neutral.  Pp.  454 U. S. 267-277.
(a) Having created a forum generally open for use by student groups
column2: the University
column3: in order to justify discriminatory exclusion from such forum based on the religious content of a group's intended speech
column4: must satisfy the standard of review appropriate to content-based exclusions; i.e.
column5: it must show that its regulation is necessary to serve a compelling state interest
column6: and that it is narrowly drawn to achieve that end.  Pp.  454 U. S. 267-270.

column1: (b) Although the University's interest in complying with its constitutional obligations under the Establishment Clause may be characterized as compelling
column2: an ""equal access"" policy would not be incompatible with that Clause.  A policy will not offend the Establishment Clause if it can pass the following three-pronged test:  (1) It has a secular legislative purpose; (2) its principal or primary effect would be neither to advance nor to inhibit religion; and (3) it does not foster ""an excessive government entanglement with religion.""  Here
column3: it is conceded that an ""equal access""

column1: policy would meet the first and third prongs of the test.  In the context of this case and in the absence of any evidence that religious groups will dominate the University's forum
column2: the advancement of religion would not be the forum's ""primary effect.""  An ""equal access"" policy would therefore satisfy the test's second prong as well.  Pp.  454 U. S. 270-275.

column1: (c) The State's interest in achieving greater separation of church and State than is already ensured under the Establishment Clause is not sufficiently ""compelling"" to justify content-based discrimination against religious speech of the student group in question.  Pp.  454 U. S. 275-276.

Held:  The principle of comity bars taxpayers' damages actions brought in federal courts under 42 U.S.C.  1983 to redress the allegedly unconstitutional administration of a state tax system.   Because the principle of comity bars federal courts from granting damages relief in such cases
column2: it is not necessary to decide whether the Tax Injunction Act
column3: standing alone
column4: would bar such actions.  Pp.  454 U. S. 107-117.

column1: (a) Prior to enactment in 1937 of the Tax Injunction Act -- which prohibits district courts from enjoining
column2: suspending
column3: or restraining the assessment
column5: or collection of any state tax where a plain
column6: speedy
column7: and efficient remedy may be had in state courts -- this Court's decisions in cases seeking federal court equitable relief against state taxation (handed down both before and after the enactment in 1871 of 42 U.S.C.  1983's predecessor) recognized that the doctrine of equitable restraint when remedies at law are adequate was particularly applicable in suits challenging the constitutionality of state tax laws because of the delicate balance between the federal authority and state governments
column8: and the concomitant respect that should be accorded state tax laws in federal court.  Pp.  454 U. S. 107-109.

column1: (b) The legislative history of the Tax Injunction Act does not suggest that Congress intended that federal court deference in state tax matters be limited to the actions enumerated in the Act.  Thus
column2: the principle of comity which predated the Act was not restricted by its passage.  Pp.  454 U. S. 109-110.

column1: (c) The post-Act vitality of the comity principle is demonstrated by this Court's 1943 decision in Great Lakes Dredge & Dock Co. v. Huffman
column3: that federal courts may not render declaratory judgments as to the constitutionality of state tax laws.  Although the Act was raised as a possible bar to the suit (as it has been raised in this case)
column4: it was found to be unnecessary to determine whether the Act could be construed to prohibit declaratory relief.  The decision was based instead on principles of federalism and the necessity of federal court respect for state taxing schemes
column5: thus demonstrating not only the post-Act vitality of the comity principle
column6: but also its applicability to actions seeking a remedy other than injunctive relief.  Pp.  454 U. S. 110-111.

column1: (d) Damages actions under  1983 would be no less disruptive of state tax systems than actions to enjoin the collection of taxes.  Recovery of damages under  1983 would first require a determination of the unconstitutionality of the state tax scheme that would be fully as intrusive as the equitable actions that are barred by comity principles.  Moreover
column2: the intrusiveness of such  1983 actions would be exacerbated by the doctrine of Monroe v. Pape
column4: authorizing immediate resort to a federal court under  1983 without first exhausting state remedies -- whenever state actions allegedly infringe constitutional rights.  In addition to the intrusiveness of the judgment
column5: the very maintenance of the suit itself would intrude on the enforcement of the state scheme.  Pp. 113-115.

column1: Appellee city of San Diego enacted an ordinance which imposes substantial prohibitions on the erection of outdoor advertising displays within the city.  The stated purpose of the ordinance is ""to eliminate hazards to pedestrians and motorists brought about by distracting sign displays"" and ""to preserve and improve the appearance of the City.""  The ordinance permits on-site commercial advertising (a sign advertising goods or services available on the property where the sign is located)
column2: but forbids other commercial advertising and noncommercial advertising using fixed-structure signs
column3: unless permitted by 1 of the ordinance's 12 specified exceptions
column4: such as temporary political campaign signs.  Appellants
column5: companies that were engaged in the outdoor advertising business in the city when the ordinance was passed
column6: brought suit in state court to enjoin enforcement of the ordinance.  The trial court held that the ordinance was an unconstitutional exercise of the city's police power and an abridgment of appellants' First Amendment rights.  The California Court of Appeal affirmed on the first ground alone
column7: but the California Supreme Court reversed
column8: holding
column10: that the ordinance was not facially invalid under the First Amendment.

column2: and the case is remanded.  Pp.  453 U. S. 498-521;  453 U. S. 527-540.

column3: but the First and Fourteenth Amendments foreclose similar interests in controlling the communicative aspects of billboards.  Because regulation of the noncommunicative aspects of a medium often impinges to some degree on the communicative aspects
column4: the courts must reconcile the government's regulatory interests with the individual's right to expression.  Pp.  453 U. S. 500-503.

column5: some noncommercial messages may be conveyed on billboards throughout the commercial and industrial zones

column1: (d) Government restrictions on protected speech are not permissible merely because the government does not favor one side over another on a subject of public controversy. column2: respondent natural gas producers and petitioner entered into a contract under which respondents agreed to sell petitioner natural gas from a certain gas field in Louisiana. The contract contained a fixed price schedule and a ""favored nations clause
column3: which provided that
column4: if petitioner purchased gas from the gas field from another party at a higher rate than it was paying respondents
column5: then respondents would be entitled to a higher price for their sales to petitioner.  In 1954
column6: respondents filed the contract and their rates with the Federal Power Commission (now the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission) and obtained from it a certificate authorizing the sale of gas at the specified contract rates.  In 1961
column7: petitioner purchased certain leases in the same gas field from the United States and began producing gas on its leasehold.  In 1974
column8: respondents filed an action in a Louisiana state court
column9: contending that petitioner's lease payments to the United States had triggered the favored nations clause.  Because petitioner had not increased its payments to respondents as required by that clause
column10: respondents sought as damages an amount equal to the difference between the price they actually were paid in the intervening years and the price they would have been paid had that clause gone into effect.  Although finding that the clause had been triggered
column11: the trial court held that the ""filed rate doctrine
column12: which prohibits a federally regulated seller of natural gas from charging rates higher than those filed with the Commission pursuant to the Natural Gas Act
column13: precluded an award of damages for the period prior to 1972 (the time during which respondents were subject to the Commission's jurisdiction).  The intermediate appellate court affirmed
column14: but the Louisiana Supreme Court reversed
column15: holding that respondents were entitled to damages for the period between 1961 and 1972 notwithstanding the filed rate doctrine.  The court reasoned that petitioner's failure to inform respondents of the lease payments to the United States had prevented respondents from filing rate increases with the Commission
column18: the increases would have been approved.

column1: Held:  The filed rate doctrine prohibits the award of damages for petitioner's breach during the period that respondents were subject to the Commission's jurisdiction.  Pp.  453 U. S. 576-585.
(a) The Natural Gas Act bars a regulated seller of natural gas from collecting a rate other than the one filed with the Commission
column2: and prevents the Commission itself from imposing a rate increase for gas already sold.  Here
column3: the Louisiana Supreme Court's ruling amounts to nothing less than the award of a retroactive rate increase based on speculation about what the Commission might have done had it been faced with the facts of this case.  This is precisely what the filed rate doctrine forbids.  It would undermine the congressional scheme of uniform rate regulation to allow a state court to award as damages a rate never filed with the Commission
column4: and thus never found to be reasonable within the meaning of the Act.  Pp.  453 U. S. 576-579.

column1: (b) Congress has granted exclusive authority over rate regulation to the Commission
column2: and
column3: in so doing
column4: withheld the authority to grant retroactive rate increases or to permit collection of a rate other than the one on file.  It would be inconsistent with this purpose to permit a state court to do through a breach of contract action what the Commission may not do.  Under the filed rate doctrine
column5: the Commission alone is empowered to approve the higher rate respondents might have filed with it
column6: and until it has done so
column7: no rate other than the one on file may be charged.  The court below thus has usurped a function that Congress has assigned to a federal regulatory body.  Cf. Chicago & North Western Transp. Co. v. Kalo Brick & Tile Co.
column8: 450 U. S. 311.  This the Supremacy Clause will not permit.  Pp.  453 U. S. 579-582.

column2: when there is a conflict between the filed rate and the contract rate
column3: the filed rate prevails.  P.  453 U. S. 582.

column1: (d) Permitting the state court to award what amounts to a retroactive right to collect a rate in excess of the filed rate ""only accentuates the danger of conflict
column2: and no appeal to equitable principles can justify such usurpation of federal authority.  Pp.  453 U. S. 583-584.

column2: the policeman smelled burnt marihuana and saw on the floor of the car an envelope suspected of containing marihuana.  He then directed the occupants to get out of the car and arrested them for unlawful possession of marihuana.  After searching each of the occupants
column3: he searched the passenger compartment of the car
column4: found a jacket belonging to respondent
column5: unzipped one of the pockets
column6: and discovered cocaine.  Subsequently
column7: respondent was indicted for criminal possession of a controlled substance.  After the trial court had denied his motion to suppress the cocaine seized from his jacket pocket
column8: respondent pleaded guilty to a lesser included offense
column9: while preserving his claim that the cocaine had been seized in violation of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.  The Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the search and seizure
column10: but the New York Court of Appeals reversed.

column1: Held:  The search of respondent's jacket was a search incident to a lawful custodial arrest
column2: and hence did not violate the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.  The jacket
column3: being located inside the passenger compartment of the car
column4: was ""within the arrestee's immediate control"" within the meaning of Chimel v. California
column6: wherein it was held that a lawful custodial arrest creates a situation justifying the contemporaneous warrantless search of the arrestee and of the immediately surrounding area.  Not only may the police search the passenger compartment of the car in such circumstances
column7: they may also examine the contents of any containers found in the passenger compartment.  And such a container may be searched whether it is open or closed
column8: since the justification for the search is not that the arrestee has no privacy interest in the container
column9: but that the lawful custodial arrest justifies the infringement of any privacy interest the arrestee may have.  Pp.  453 U. S. 457-463.

column1: A regular commissioned officer of the United States Army who retires after 20 years of service is entitled to retired pay.  Retired pay terminates with the officer's death
column2: although he may designate a beneficiary to receive any arrearages that remain unpaid at death.  In addition
column3: there are statutory plans that allow the officer to set aside a portion of his retired pay for his survivors.  Appellant
column5: filed a petition in California Superior Court for dissolution of his marriage to appellee.  At the time
column6: he had served approximately 18 of the 20 years required for retirement with pay.  Under California law
column7: each spouse
column8: upon dissolution of a marriage
column9: has an equal and absolute right to a half interest in all community and quasi-community property
column10: but retains his or her separate property.  In his petition
column13: that his military retirement benefits be confirmed to him as his separate property.  The Superior Court held
column15: that such benefits were subject to division as quasi-community property
column16: and accordingly ordered appellant to pay to appellee a specified portion of the benefits upon retirement.  Subsequently
column17: appellant retired and began receiving retired pay; under the dissolution decree
column18: appellee was entitled to approximately 45% of the retired pay.  On review of this award
column19: the California Court of Appeal affirmed
column21: because the federal scheme of military retirement benefits preempts state community property law
column22: the Supremacy Clause precluded the trial court from awarding appellee a portion of his retired pay.

column1: Held:  Federal law precludes a state court from dividing military retired pay pursuant to state community property laws.  Pp.  453 U. S. 220-236.

(a) There is a conflict between the terms of the federal military retirement statutes and the community property right asserted by appellee.  The military retirement system confers no entitlement to retired pay upon the retired member's spouse
column2: and does not embody even a limited ""community property concept.""  Rather
column3: the language
column5: and history of the statutes make it clear that retired pay continues to be the personal entitlement of the retiree.  Pp.  453 U. S. 221-232.

column2: the application of community property principles to military retired pay threatens grave harm to ""clear and substantial""
the community property division of retired pay
column3: by reducing the amounts that Congress has determined are necessary for the retired member
column4: has the potential to frustrate the congressional objective of providing for the retired service member.  In addition
column5: such a division has the potential to interfere with the congressional goals of having the military retirement system serve as an inducement for enlistment and reenlistment and as an encouragement to orderly promotion and a youthful military.  Pp.  453 U. S. 232-235.

column1: The Military Selective Service Act (Act) authorizes the President to require the registration for possible military service of males
column2: but not females
column3: the purpose of registration being to facilitate any eventual conscription under the Act.  Registration for the draft was discontinued by Presidential Proclamation in 1975 (the Act was amended in 1973 to preclude conscription)
column4: but as the result of a crisis in Southwestern Asia
column5: President Carter decided in 1980 that it was necessary to reactivate the registration process
column6: and sought Congress' allocation of funds for that purpose.  He also recommended that Congress amend the Act to permit the registration and conscription of women as well as men.  Although agreeing that it was necessary to reactivate the registration process
column7: Congress allocated only those funds necessary to register males
column8: and declined to amend the Act to permit the registration of women.  Thereafter
column9: the President ordered the registration of specified groups of young men.  In a lawsuit brought by several men challenging the Act's constitutionality
column10: a three-judge District Court ultimately held that the Act's gender-based discrimination violated the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment
column11: and enjoined registration under the Act.

column1: Held:  The Act's registration provisions do not violate the Fifth Amendment.  Congress acted well within its constitutional authority to raise and regulate armies and navies when it authorized the registration of men and not women.  Pp.  453 U. S. 64-83.
(a) The customary deference accorded Congress' judgments is particularly appropriate when
column2: as here
column3: Congress specifically considered the question of the Act's constitutionality
column4: and perhaps in no area has the Court accorded Congress greater deference than in the area of national defense and military affairs.  While Congress is not free to disregard the Constitution when it acts in the area of military affairs
column5: this Court must be particularly careful not to substitute its judgment of what is desirable for that of Congress
column6: or its own evaluation of evidence for a reasonable evaluation by the Legislative Branch.  Congress carefully considered whether to register only males for potential conscription or whether to register both sexes
column7: and its broad constitutional authority

column1: cannot be ignored in considering the constitutionality of its studied choice of one alternative in preference to the other.  Pp.  453 U. S. 64-72.
(b) The question of registering women was extensively considered by Congress in hearings held in response to the President's request for authorization to register women
column2: and its decision to exempt women was not the accidental byproduct of a traditional way of thinking about women.  Since Congress thoroughly reconsidered the question of exempting women from the Act in 1980
column3: the Act's constitutionality need not be considered solely on the basis of the views expressed by Congress in 1948
column4: when the Act was first enacted in its modern form.  Congress' determination that any future draft would be characterized by a need for combat troops was sufficiently supported by testimony adduced at the hearings so that the courts are not free to make their own judgment on the question.   And since women are excluded from combat service by statute or military policy
column5: men and women are simply not similarly situated for purposes of a draft or registration for a draft
column6: and Congress' decision to authorize the registration of only men therefore does not violate the Due Process Clause.  The testimony of executive and military officials before Congress showed that the argument for registering women was based on considerations of equity
column7: but Congress was entitled
column8: in the exercise of its constitutional powers
column9: to focus on the question of military need
column10: rather than ""equity.""  The District Court
column11: undertaking an independent evaluation of the evidence
column12: exceeded its authority in ignoring Congress' conclusions that whatever the need for women for noncombat roles during mobilization
column13: it could be met by volunteers
column14: and that staffing noncombat positions with women during a mobilization would be positively detrimental to the important goal of military flexibility.  Pp.  453 U. S. 72-83.

column1: "|"United States Postal Service v. Council of
Title 18 U.S.C.  1725 prohibits the deposit of unstamped ""mailable matter"" in a letterbox approved by the United States Postal Service
column2: and violations are subject to a fine.  The local Postmaster notified appellee civic association that its practice of delivering messages to residents by placing unstamped notices in the letterboxes of private homes violated  1725
column3: and advised it that
column4: if it and other members of appellee council of civic associations continued such practice
column5: it could result in a fine.  Appellees then brought suit in Federal District Court against the Postal Service for declaratory and injunctive relief
column6: contending that the enforcement of  1725 would inhibit their communications with local residents and would thereby deny them the freedom of speech and press secured by the First Amendment.  The District Court ultimately declared  1725 unconstitutional as applied to appellees and the council's member associations and enjoined the Postal Service from enforcing it as to them.

column1: Held:  Section 1725 does not unconstitutionally abridge appellees' First Amendment rights
column2: inasmuch as neither the enactment nor the enforcement of  1725 is geared in any way to the content of the message sought to be placed in the letterbox.  Pp.  453 U. S. 120-134.

column1: (a) When a letterbox is designated an ""authorized depository"" of the mail by the Postal Service
column2: it becomes an essential part of the nationwide system for the delivery and receipt of mail.  In effect
column3: the postal customer
column4: although he pays for the physical components of the ""authorized depository
column5: agrees to abide by the Postal Service's regulations in exchange for the Postal Service agreeing to deliver and pick up his mail.  A letterbox
column6: once designated an ""authorized depository
column7: does not at the same time transform itself into a ""public forum"" of some limited nature to which the First Amendment guarantees access to all comers.  Just because it may be somewhat more efficient for appellees to place their messages in letterboxes does not mean that there is a First Amendment right to do so.  The First Amendment does not guarantee access to property simply because it is owned or controlled by the Government.  Pp.  453 U. S. 126-131.

column2: in exercising its constitutional authority to develop and operate a national postal system
column3: may properly legislate with the generality of cases in mind
column4: and should not be put to the test of defending in one township after another the constitutionality of a statute under the traditional ""time
column5: place
column6: and manner"" analysis.  If Congress and the Postal Service are to operate as efficiently as possible an extensive system for the delivery of mail
column7: they must adopt regulations of a general character having uniform applicability throughout the Nation.  In this case
column8: Congress was legislating to promote what it considered to be the efficiency of the Postal Service
column9: and was not laying down a generalized prohibition against the distribution of leaflets or the discussion of issues in traditional public forums.  Pp.  453 U. S. 133-133.

column2: by its own ipse dixit
column3: destroy the ""public forum"" status of streets and parks
column4: a letterbox may not properly be analogized to streets and parks.  Pp.  453 U. S. 133-134.

column1: Association of Journeymen & Apprentices of the

Held:  A suit brought by respondent local union against petitioner parent international union alleging a violation of the international union's constitution arising from the international union's issuance of an order requiring consolidation of certain local unions
column2: including respondent -- which suit was instituted in state court but removed to federal court by the international union -- falls within the jurisdiction of the federal district courts under  301(a) of the Labor Management Relations Act
column3: 1947.  That section establishes such jurisdiction for ""[s]uits for violation of contracts . . . between any . . . labor organizations"" representing employees in a covered industry.  A union constitution is a ""contract between labor organizations"" and the unions are ""labor organizations"" within the plain meaning of  301(a)
column4: and there is no legislative history contrary to such an interpretation.  Section 301(a) jurisdiction over disputes between local and parent unions based on the parent's constitution does not depend upon allegations that the dispute potentially could have a significant impact on labor-management relations or industrial peace.  Congress could have concluded that the enforcement of the terms of union constitutions -- documents that prescribe the legal relationship and the rights and obligations between the parent and affiliated locals -- would contribute to the achievement of labor stability.  Pp.  452 U. S. 619627.

column3: first-served basis -- open to the kind of arbitrary application that is inherently inconsistent with a valid time
column5: and manner regulation as having the potential for becoming a means of suppressing a particular point of view.  Pp.  452 U. S. 648-649.

column5: sell wares

column2: a company engaged in the business of providing housekeeping
column3: cleaning
column5: and related services for commercial customers
column6: had a contract to do maintenance work for a nursing home.  As a result of a dispute with the home over the size of the management fee
column7: petitioner terminated the contract
column8: and petitioner's employees who worked at the nursing home were discharged.  While the contract was still in effect
column9: a labor union was certified as the bargaining representative for petitioner's employees at the nursing home.  The union
column10: upon learning of petitioner's intention to discharge these employees
column11: requested a delay from petitioner for the purpose of bargaining
column12: but petitioner refused to bargain.  The union then filed an unfair labor practice charge against petitioner
column13: alleging violation of its duty to bargain in good faith ""with respect to wages
column15: and other terms and conditions of employment"" under  8(d) and 8(a)(5) of the National Labor Relations Act.  The National Labor Relations Board upheld the charge and ordered petitioner
column16: if it agreed to resume the nursing home operations
column17: to reinstate the discharged employees or
column19: to offer the employees equivalent jobs at its other operations.  The Court of Appeals enforced the Board's order
column21: while no per se rule could be formulated to govern an employer's decision to close part of its business
column22: 8(d) creates a presumption in favor of mandatory bargaining over such a decision
column23: which presumption is rebuttable by showing that the purposes of the NLRA would not be furthered by imposing a duty to bargain.

column1: Held:  Although required to bargain about the effects of such a decision
column2: petitioner had no duty to bargain over its decision to terminate the nursing home contract.  The facts of Fibreboard Paper Products Corp. v. NLRB

column1: (a) In view of an employer's need for unencumbered decisionmaking in the conduct of its business

column3: for labor-management relations

column2: outweighs the burden placed on the conduct of the business.  Pp.  452 U. S. 674-680.

column1: (b) The harm likely to be done to an employer's need to operate freely in deciding whether to shut down part of its business purely for economic reasons outweighs the incremental benefit that might be gained through the union's participation in making that decision. column1: When police officers executing a warrant to search a house for narcotics encountered respondent descending the front steps
column2: they requested his assistance in gaining entry and detained him while they searched the premises.  After finding narcotics and ascertaining that respondent owned the house
column3: the police arrested him
column5: and found heroin in his coat pocket.  Respondent
column6: who was charged with possession of the heroin found on his person
column7: moved to suppress the heroin as the product of an illegal search in violation of the Fourth Amendment.  The trial judge granted the motion and quashed the information
column8: and both the Michigan Court of Appeals and the Michigan Supreme Court affirmed.

column1: Held:  The initial detention of respondent
column2: which constituted a ""seizure"" and was assumed to be unsupported by probable cause
column3: did not violate his constitutional right to be secure against an unreasonable seizure of his person.  For Fourth Amendment purposes
column4: a warrant to search for contraband founded on probable cause implicitly carries with it the limited authority to detain the occupants of the premises while a proper search is conducted.  Because it was lawful to require respondent to reenter and to remain in the house until evidence establishing probable cause to arrest him was found
column5: his arrest and the search incident thereto were constitutionally permissible.  Pp.  452 U. S. 694-705.

column3: reversed.

|452 u.s. 714|New York State Liquor Authority v. Bellanca

Held.  A provision of New York's Alcoholic Beverage Control Law prohibiting nude dancing in establishments licensed by the State to sell liquor for on-premises consumption is not unconstitutional as violating the First Amendment on the alleged ground that it prohibits nonobscene topless dancing
column2: but instead is valid as being within the State's broad power under the Twenty-first Amendment to regulate the sale of liquor within its boundaries.  Cf. California v. LaRue
column3: 409 U. S. 109.  The State's power to ban the sale of alcoholic beverages entirely includes the lesser power to ban the sale of liquor on premises where topless dancing occurs.  Whatever artistic or communicative value may attach to topless dancing is overcome by the State's exercise of its broad power under the Twenty-first Amendment.
reversed and remanded.

column1: "|"New York State Liquor Authority v. Bellanca

Held.  A provision of New York's Alcoholic Beverage Control Law prohibiting nude dancing in establishments licensed by the State to sell liquor for on-premises consumption is not unconstitutional as violating the First Amendment on the alleged ground that it prohibits nonobscene topless dancing
column2: but instead is valid as being within the State's broad power under the Twenty-first Amendment to regulate the sale of liquor within its boundaries.  Cf. California v. LaRue
column3: 409 U. S. 109.  The State's power to ban the sale of alcoholic beverages entirely includes the lesser power to ban the sale of liquor on premises where topless dancing occurs.  Whatever artistic or communicative value may attach to topless dancing is overcome by the State's exercise of its broad power under the Twenty-first Amendment.
reversed and remanded."|

column1: A preenforcement challenge to the constitutionality of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 (Act) was presented in a Federal District Court action wherein the plaintiffs were an association of coal producers engaged in surface coal mining operations in Virginia
column2: some of its member coal companies
column3: individual landowners
column5: and a town (hereinafter appellees).  The Act is designed to establish a nationwide program to protect society and the environment from the adverse effects of surface coal mining operations.  The Secretary of the Interior (Secretary) has primary responsibility for administering the Act by promulgating regulations and enforcing its provisions.  A two-stage program for the regulation of surface mining -- an interim phase and a permanent phase -- is established; and environmental protection performance standards are prescribed.  Ultimately
column6: a regulatory program is to be adopted for each State
column7: either by approval of a State's proposed permanent program that meets federal minimum standards or by adoption of a federal program for any State that chooses not to submit a program.  Enforcement of the permanent programs rests either with the participating State or with the Secretary as to nonparticipating States.  The District Court
column8: although rejecting appellees' Commerce Clause
column10: and substantive due process challenges to the Act
column11: held that the Act violates the Tenth Amendment

column13: and that some of the Act's enforcement provisions violate procedural due process requirements.

column5: set out in the Act itself
column6: that surface coal mining has substantial effects on interstate commerce.  And the Act's regulatory scheme is reasonably related to the goals Congress sought to accomplish -- the Act's restrictions on the practices of mine operators all serving to control the environmental and other adverse effects of surface coal mining.  Pp.  452 U. S. 275-283.

column7: except for  522(e)

These provisions include  510(d)(1)
column2: which requires an applicant for a permit for mining on prime farmland to show that he has the capacity to restore the land
column3: within a reasonable time after the completion of mining
column4: to the productivity level of prime farmland in the surrounding area;  519(c)(2)
column5: which conditions release of a mine operator's bond on the completion of such restoration; and  508(a)(2)
column6: which directs mine operators to include information about the premining productivity of the land in the reclamation plans filed as part of permit applications.  The general provisions in question include  515(b)(3)
column7: which requires restoration of mined land to its approximate original contour;  515(b)(5)
column8: which requires surface mine operators to remove topsoil separately and preserve it for use during reclamation;  508
column9: which requires applicants for surface mining permits to submit reclamation plans;  522(a)
column12: which require States wishing to regulate surface mining to establish an administrative procedure for determining whether particular lands are unsuitable for surface mining;  522(e)
column13: which proscribes mining within a specified distance of roads
column19: or dwellings; and the Act's procedures for collecting civil penalties from violators of the Act
column20: including a requirement that a contested penalty be paid into an escrow account pending review.  Appellees (the State of Indiana and several of its officials
column23: and others) filed suits in Federal District Court
column24: alleging that the provisions in question contravene the Commerce Clause
column25: the equal protection and due process guarantees of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment
column27: and the Just Compensation Clause of the Fifth Amendment.  The District Court sustained each of the constitutional

column2: the environment
column3: or public health and safety
column4: and to protect mine operators in States adhering to high performance and reclamation standards from disadvantageous competition with operators in States with less rigorous regulatory programs.  The challenged provisions advance these legitimate goals
column5: and Congress acted reasonably in adopting the regulatory scheme contained in the Act.  Pp.  452 U. S. 321-329.

column1: (b) Nor do the challenged provisions contravene the Tenth Amendment.  Such provisions regulate only the activities of surface mine operators who are private individuals and businesses
column2: and do not directly regulate the States as States.  P.  452 U. S. 330.

column1: Held:  The Bennett Amendment does not restrict Title VII's prohibition of sex-based wage discrimination to claims for equal pay for ""equal work.""  Rather
column2: claims for sex-based wage discrimination can also be brought under Title VII even though no member of the opposite sex holds an equal but higher paying job

column5: quantity or quality of production
column6: or any other factor other than sex.  Pp.  452 U. S. 167-181.

column1: (a) The language of the Bennett Amendment -- barring sex-based wage discrimination claims under Title VII where the pay differential is ""authorized"" by the Equal Pay Act -- suggests an intention to incorporate into Title VII only the affirmative defenses of the Equal Pay Act
column2: not its prohibitory language requiring equal pay for equal work
column3: which language does not ""authorize"" anything at all.  Nor does this construction of the Amendment render it superfluous.  Although the first three affirmative defenses are redundant of provisions elsewhere in  703(h) of Title VII
column4: the Bennett Amendment guarantees a consistent interpretation of like provisions in both statutes.  More importantly
column5: incorporation of the fourth affirmative defense could have significant consequences for Title VII litigation.  Pp.  452 U. S. 168-171.

column1: (b) The Bennett Amendment's legislative background is fully consistent with this interpretation
column2: and does not support an alternative ruling.  Pp.  452 U. S. 171-176.

column3: in its capacity as amicus curiae
column4: now supports respondents' position.  Pp.  452 U. S. 177-178.

column1: Petitioner Gulf Oil Co. and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission entered into a conciliation agreement involving alleged discrimination against black and female employees at one of Gulf's refineries.  Under this agreement
column2: Gulf undertook to offer backpay to alleged victims of discrimination and began to send notices to employees eligible for backpay
column3: stating the amount available in return for execution of a full release of all discrimination claims.  Respondents then filed a class action in Federal District Court against Gulf and petitioner labor union
column4: on behalf of all black present and former employees and rejected applicants for employment
column5: alleging racial discrimination in employment and seeking injunctive
column6: declaratory
column7: and monetary relief.  Gulf then filed a motion seeking an order limiting communications from the named plaintiffs (respondents) and their counsel to class members.  Ultimately
column8: over respondents' objections
column9: the District Court issued an order
column10: based on the form of order in the Manual for Complex Litigation
column11: imposing a complete ban on all communications concerning the class action between parties or their counsel and any actual or potential class member who was not a formal party
column12: without the court's prior approval.  The order stated that
column13: if any party or counsel asserted a constitutional right to communicate without prior restraint and did so communicate
column14: he must file a copy of the communication with the court.  The court made no findings of fact
column15: and did not write an explanatory opinion.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column16: holding that the order limiting communications was an unconstitutional prior restraint on expression accorded First Amendment protection.

column1: Held:  The District Court in imposing the order in question abused its discretion under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.  Pp.  452 U. S. 99-104.

column2: such an order should be based on a clear record and specific findings reflecting a weighing of the need for a limitation and the potential interference with the parties' rights.  Only such a determination can ensure that the court is furthering
column3: rather than hindering
column4: the policies embodied in the Federal Rules
column5: especially Rule 23.  Moreover
column6: such a weighing should result in a carefully drawn order that limits speech as little as possible
column7: consistent with the parties' rights.  Pp.  452 U. S. 101-102.

column2: there is no indication of a careful weighing of competing factors

column1: Petitioner and respondents manufacture and sell ready-mix concrete.  A purchaser of concrete from petitioner filed a civil action against petitioner in Federal District Court
column2: alleging that petitioner and certain unnamed firms had conspired to raise concrete prices in violation of  1 of the Sherman Act
column3: and seeking treble damages under  4 of the Clayton Act.  After learning through discovery that respondents were the alleged coconspirators
column4: petitioner filed a third-party complaint against them
column5: seeking contribution should it be held liable in the original action.  The District Court dismissed the third-party complaint for failure to state a claim upon which relief could be granted
column6: holding that federal law does not allow an antitrust defendant to recover in contribution from alleged coconspirators.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  There is no basis in federal statutory or common law for allowing federal courts to fashion the right to contribution urged by petitioner.  Pp.  451 U. S. 634-647.
(a) Congress neither expressly nor implicitly intended to create such a right to contribution.  Nothing in the Sherman and Clayton Acts or in their legislative history refers to contribution
column2: and there is nothing to indicate any congressional concern with softening the blow on joint wrongdoers.  Rather
column3: the very idea of treble damages reveals an intent to punish past
column5: unlawful conduct
column6: not to ameliorate the liability of joint wrongdoers.  Pp.  451 U. S. 639-640.

column1: (b) The federal courts are not empowered to fashion a federal common law rule of contribution among antitrust wrongdoers.  Contribution does not implicate ""uniquely federal interests"" of the kind that oblige courts to formulate federal common law.  Moreover
column2: even though Congress may have intended to allow federal courts to develop governing principles of law in the common law tradition with regard to substantive violations of the Sherman Act
column3: it does not follow that Congress intended to give courts as wide discretion in formulating remedies to enforce the Act or the kind of relief sought through contribution.  There is nothing in the Act itself
column5: or in the overall

column1: legislative scheme to suggest that Congress intended courts to have the power to alter or supplement the remedies enacted.  Pp.  451 U. S. 640-646.
(c) Regardless of the merits of the conflicting arguments on the complex policy questions presented by petitioner's claimed right to contribution
column2: this is a matter for Congress
column3: not the courts to resolve.  Pp.  451 U. S. 646-647.

column2: affirmed.

column6: however

column9: alleging that the union had breached its duty of fair representation
column10: and that the employer had breached the collective bargaining agreement by discharging him without just cause. The District Court sustained the union and the employer's affirmative defense that the employee had failed to exhaust the internal union appeals procedures
column11: and accordingly dismissed the suit against both the union and the employer.  The Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal of the suit against the union
column12: but reversed the dismissal against the employer.  The court held that the employee's failure to exhaust was fatal to his claim against the union because
column14: he might have received money damages
column15: the relief he sought in his  301 suit against the union.  But the court held that the employee's failure to exhaust did not bar his suit against the employer

column2: he should not have been required to exhaust such procedures prior to bringing suit against the union and the employer under  301(a).  Pp.  451 U. S. 685-696.
in contrast to contractual grievance and arbitration procedures negotiated by the parties to a collective bargaining agreement
column3: are created by the union constitution and are designed to settle disputes between an employee and his union arising under the constitution
column4: the policies encouraging private resolution of grievances arising out of the collective bargaining process are not directly applicable to the issue whether to require exhaustion of internal union procedures.  Republic Steel Corp. v. Maddox
column6: distinguished.  Such policies are furthered by an exhaustion requirement only where the internal procedures can either grant the aggrieved employee full relief or reactivate his grievance.  Pp.  451 U. S. 685-689.

column1: (b) If the internal procedures are inadequate to effect the relief sought by the employee
column2: his failure to exhaust should be excused
column3: and he should be permitted to pursue his claim for breach of the duty of fair representation and breach of the collective bargaining agreement in court under  301.  Here
column4: although it appears that some monetary relief could be obtained through the internal procedures

column3: with the possible result that the court would find itself with two separate  301 suits based on the same facts proceeding at different paces in its courtroom.  Pp.  451 U. S. 694-695.

column3: ordered by the trial court to determine respondent's competency to stand trial and conducted in the jail where he was being held
column4: the examining doctor determined that respondent was competent.  Thereafter
column5: respondent was tried by a jury and convicted.  A separate sentencing proceeding was then held before the same jury
column6: as required by Texas law.  At such a proceeding
column7: the jury must resolve three critical issues to determine whether or not the death sentence will be imposed.  One of these issues involves the future dangerousness of the defendant
column8: i.e.
column9: whether there is a probability that he would commit criminal acts of violence that would constitute a continuing threat to society.  At the sentencing hearing
column10: the doctor who had conducted the pretrial psychiatric examination was allowed to testify for the State over defense counsels' objection that his name did not appear on the list of witnesses the State planned to use at either the guilt or penalty stages of the proceedings.  His testimony was based on the pretrial examination
column11: and stated in substance that respondent would be a danger to society.  The jury then resolved the issue of future dangerousness
column12: as well as the other two issues
column16: the death penalty was mandatory.  The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals affirmed the conviction and death sentence.  After unsuccessfully seeking a writ of habeas corpus in the state courts
column17: respondent petitioned for such relief in Federal District Court.  That court vacated the death sentence because it found constitutional error in admitting the doctor's testimony at the penalty phase.  The United States Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: 1. The admission of the doctor's testimony at the penalty phase violated respondent's Fifth Amendment privilege against compelled self-incrimination
column2: because he was not advised before the pretrial psychiatric examination that he had a right to remain silent and that any statement he made could be used against him at a capital sentencing proceeding.  Pp.  451 U. S. 461-469.

column1: (a) There is no basis for distinguishing between the guilt and penalty

phases of respondent's trial so far as the protection of the Fifth Amendment privilege is concerned.  The State's attempt to establish respondent's future dangerousness by relying on the unwarned statements he made to the examining doctor infringed the Fifth Amendment just as much as would have any effort to compel respondent to testify against his will at the sentencing hearing.  Pp.  451 U. S. 462-463.

(b) The Fifth Amendment privilege is directly involved here because the State used as evidence against respondent the substance of his disclosures during the pretrial psychiatric examination.  The fact that respondent's statements were made in the context of such an examination does not automatically remove them from the reach of that Amendment.  Pp.  451 U. S. 463-466.

(c) The considerations calling for the accused to be warned prior to custodial interrogation apply with no less force to the pretrial psychiatric examination at issue here.  An accused who neither initiates a psychiatric evaluation nor attempts to introduce any psychiatric evidence may not be compelled to respond to a psychiatrist if his statements can be used against him at a capital sentencing proceeding.  When faced while in custody with a court-ordered psychiatric inquiry
column2: respondent's statements to the doctor were not ""given freely and voluntarily without any compelling influences"" and
column3: as such
column4: could be used as the State did at the penalty phase only if respondent had been apprised of his rights and had knowingly decided to waive them.  Miranda v. Arizona
column6: 384 U. S. 478.  Since these safeguards of the Fifth Amendment privilege were not afforded respondent
column7: his death sentence cannot stand.  Pp.  451 U. S. 466-469.

column1: 2. Respondent's Sixth Amendment right to the assistance of counsel also was violated by the State's introduction of the doctor's testimony at the penalty phase.  Such right already had attached when the doctor examined respondent in jail
column2: and that interview proved to be a ""critical stage"" of the aggregate proceedings against respondent.  Defense counsel were not notified in advance that the psychiatric examination would encompass the issue of their client's future dangerousness
column3: and respondent was denied the assistance of his counsel in making the significant decision of whether to submit to the examination and to what end the psychiatrist's findings could be employed.  Pp.  451 U. S. 469-471.

column1: After being arrested on a state criminal charge
column2: and after being informed of his rights as required by Miranda v. Arizona
column4: petitioner was questioned by the police on January 19
column6: until he said that he wanted an attorney.  Questioning then ceased
column7: but on January 20
column8: police officers came to the jail and
column9: after stating that they wanted to talk to him and again informing petitioner of his Miranda rights
column10: obtained his confession when he said that he was willing to talk.  The trial court ultimately denied petitioner's motion to suppress his confession
column11: finding the statement to be voluntary
column12: and he was thereafter convicted.  The Arizona Supreme Court held that
column14: he waived his right to remain silent and his right to counsel when he voluntarily gave his statement after again being informed of his rights.

column1: Held:  The use of petitioner's confession against him at his trial violated his right under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments to have counsel present during custodial interrogation
column2: as declared in Miranda
column3: supra.  Having exercised his right on January 19 to have counsel present during interrogation
column4: petitioner did not validly waive that right on the 20th.  Pp.  451 U. S. 481-487.

column1: (a) A waiver of the right to counsel
column2: once invoked
column3: not only must be voluntary
column4: but also must constitute a knowing and intelligent relinquishment of a known right or privilege.  Here
column5: however
column6: the state courts applied an erroneous standard for determining waiver by focusing on the voluntariness of petitioner's confession
column7: rather than on whether he understood his right to counsel and intelligently and knowingly relinquished it.  Pp.  451 U. S. 482-84.

column2: a valid waiver of that right cannot be established by showing only that he responded to police-initiated interrogation after being again advised of his rights.  An accused

column4: having expressed his desire to deal with the police only through counsel
column5: is not subject to further interrogation until counsel has been made available to him
column6: unless the accused has himself initiated further communication

column2: and his confession
column3: made without having had access to counsel
column4: did not amount to a valid waiver
column5: and hence was inadmissible.  Pp.  451 U. S. 484-487.

column1: This case involves a custody dispute between the mother (petitioner) and father (respondent) of a minor child.  A Florida state court awarded custody to petitioner.  In a subsequently filed action
column2: a Georgia state court awarded custody to respondent
column3: and the Georgia Supreme Court affirmed.  Petitioner then filed a petition for certiorari in this Court
column4: raising the question whether Art. IV
column6: of the Federal Constitution required Georgia to give full faith and credit to the Florida decree
column7: and certiorari was granted.

column1: Held:  Where the record discloses that petitioner failed to raise her federal claim in the Georgia courts and that the Georgia Supreme Court failed to rule on a federal issue
column2: this Court is without jurisdiction to decide that issue
column3: and accordingly the writ of certiorari is dismissed.  Pp.  451 U. S. 494-502.

column1: In two suits initiated in New Jersey state court
column2: retired employees who had received workers' compensation awards subsequent to retirement challenged the validity of provisions in their employers' pension plans reducing a retiree's pension benefits by an amount equal to a workers' compensation award for which the retiree is eligible.  These private pension plans are subject to federal regulation under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).  The employers independently removed the suits to Federal District Court
column3: where the judges in each suit held that the pension offset provisions were invalid under a provision of the New Jersey Workers' Compensation Act prohibiting such offsets; that Congress had not intended ERISA to preempt such state laws; that the offsets were prohibited by ERISA's provision
column5: prohibiting forfeitures of pension rights except under specified conditions inapplicable to these cases; and that a Treasury Regulation authorizing offsets based on workers' compensation awards was invalid.  The Court of Appeals consolidated appeals from the two decisions
column6: and reversed.

column1: 1. Congress contemplated and approved the kind of pension provisions challenged here.  Pp.  451 U. S. 509-521.
(a) Pension plan provisions for offsets based on workers' compensation awards do not contravene ERISA's nonforfeiture provisions.  While  1053(a) prohibits forfeitures of vested rights
column2: with specified exceptions that do not include workers' compensation offsets
column3: nevertheless other provisions make it clear that ERISA leaves to the private parties creating the pension plan the determination of the content or amount of benefits that
column5: cannot be forfeited.  The statutory definition of ""nonforfeitable"" pension benefits
column7: assures that an employee's claim to the protected benefit is legally enforceable
column8: but it does not guarantee a particular amount or a method for calculating the benefit.  Cf. Nachman Corp. v. Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp.

column1: It is particularly pertinent that Congress did not prohibit ""integration
column2: a calculation practice under which benefit levels are determined by combining pension funds with other public income streams available to the retired employee.  Rather
column3: Congress accepted the practice by expressly preserving the option of pension fund integration with benefits available under both the Social Security Act and the Railroad Retirement Act.  Offsets against pension benefits for workers' compensation awards work much like the integration of pension benefits with Social Security or Railroad Retirement payments
column4: and thus the nonforfeiture provision of  1053(a) has no more applicability to the former kind of integration than it does to the latter.  Pp.  451 U. S. 510-517.

column1: (b) Although neither ERISA nor its legislative history mentions integration with workers' compensation
column2: ERISA does not forbid the Treasury Regulation permitting reductions of pension benefits based on awards under state workers' compensation laws
column3: or Internal Revenue Service rulings to the same effect.  There is no merit in the argument that integration of pension funds with workers' compensation awards
column4: which are based on work-related injuries
column5: lacks the rationale behind ERISA's permission of integration of pension funds with Social Security and Railroad Retirement payments
column6: which supply payments for wages lost due to retirement.  Both the Social Security and Railroad Retirement Acts also provide payments for disability
column7: and ERISA permits pension integration with such benefits
column8: as well as with benefits for wages lost due to retirement.  Moreover
column10: Congress knew of the IRS rulings permitting integration with workers' compensation benefits and left them in effect.  Pp.  451 U. S. 517-521.

column1: 2. The New Jersey statute in question is preempted by federal law insofar as it eliminates a method for calculating pension benefits under plans governed by ERISA.  The provision of ERISA
column3: stating that the Act's provisions shall supersede any state laws that ""relate to any [covered] employee benefit plan
column4: demonstrates that Congress meant to establish pension plan regulation as exclusively a federal concern.  Regardless of whether the purpose of the New Jersey statute might have been to protect the employee's right to workers' compensation disability benefits
column5: rather than to regulate pension plans
column6: the statute ""relate[s] to pension plans"" governed by ERISA because it eliminates one method for calculating pension benefits -- integration -- that is permitted by federal law
column7: and the state provision thus is an impermissible intrusion on the federal regulatory scheme.  It is of no moment that New Jersey intrudes indirectly
column8: through a workers' compensation law
column10: through a statute called ""pension

column2: since ERISA makes clear that even indirect state action bearing on private pensions may encroach upon the area of exclusive federal concern.  Moreover
column3: where
column5: pension plans emerge from collective bargaining
column6: the additional federal interest in precluding state interference in labor-management negotiations calls for preemption of state efforts to regulate pension term.  Pp.  451 U. S. 521-526.

column2: an inmate of a Nebraska prison
column3: ordered by mail certain hobby materials.  After being delivered to the prison
column4: the packages containing the materials were lost when the normal procedure for receipt of mail packages was not followed.  Respondent brought an action in Federal District Court under 42 U.S.C.  1983 against petitioner prison officials to recover the value of the hobby materials
column5: claiming that petitioners had negligently lost the materials
column6: and thereby deprived respondent of property without due process of law in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment.  The District Court entered summary judgment for respondent
column7: holding that negligent actions by state officials can be a basis for an action under  1983
column8: that petitioners were not immune from liability
column9: and that the deprivation of the hobby materials implicated due process rights.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  Respondent has not stated a claim for relief under 42 U.S.C.  1983.  Pp.  451 U. S. 531-544.

column2: the initial inquiry must focus on whether the two essential elements to a  1983 action are present:  (1) whether the conduct complained of was committed by a person acting under color of state law; and (2) whether this conduct deprived a person of rights
column3: privileges
column4: or immunities secured by the Constitution or laws of the United States.  Pp.  451 U. S. 531-535.

column1: (b) Although respondent has been deprived of property under color of state law
column2: he has not sufficiently alleged a violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.  The deprivation did not occur as the result of some established state procedure
column3: but as the result of the unauthorized failure of state agents to follow established state procedure.  Moreover
column4: Nebraska has a tort claims procedure which provides a remedy to persons who have suffered a tortious loss at the hands of the State
column5: but which respondent did not use.  Such procedure could have fully compensated respondent for his property loss
column6: and was sufficient to satisfy the requirements of due process.  Pp.  451 U. S. 535-544.

column1: Held:  The ""percentage depletion"" allowance under  611 and 613 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 -- whereby the owner of an economic interest in a mineral deposit is allowed a special deduction from taxable income measured by a percentage of his gross income derived from exhaustion of the mineral -- may not be denied to respondent lessees of underground coal who had the right to extract and sell the coal at prices fixed by them
column2: paying a fixed royalty per ton to their lessors
column3: merely because their leases were subject to termination by the lessor on 30 days' notice.  Pp.  451 U. S. 576-585.

column1: (a) The deduction provides a special incentive for engaging in the mining business that goes well beyond a purpose of merely allowing the owner of a wasting asset to recoup the capital invested in that asset
column2: and hence eligibility for the deduction is determined not by the amount of the capital investment
column3: but by the mine operator's ""economic interest"" in the coal.  The question here is whether the deduction for the asset depleted by respondents will be received by anyone
column4: since the tax consequences of the lessors' receipt of royalties will not be affected
column5: either favorably or unfavorably
column6: by the decision.  Pp.  451 U. S. 576-579.

column2: respondents had a legal interest in the coal both before and after it was mined
column3: and were free to sell the coal at whatever price the market could bear.  Thus
column4: they had a depletable ""economic interest"" in the coal deposits
column5: not merely an ""economic advantage.""  Parsons v. Smith
column7: and Paragon Jewel Coal Co. v. Commissioner
column9: distinguished.  Nor does the right to terminate give the lessor the only significant economic interest in the coal as a matter of ""practical economics.""  It is by no means certain that an increase in the price of coal will induce a lessor to terminate a satisfactory business relationship
column10: and it would be unfair to deny a lessee a tax benefit that is available to competitors simply because he accepted the business risk of termination that his competitors were able to avoid when they negotiated their mining leases.  Moreover
column11: the Government has not suggested any rational basis for linking the right to a depletion deduction to the period of time that the taxpayer operates a mine.  Thus
column12: the mere existence of the lessors' unexercised

column1: right to terminate respondents' leases did not destroy their economic interest in the leased mineral deposits.  Pp.  451 U. S. 579-585.

column1: Section 33(b) of the Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act provides that a longshoreman's acceptance
column2: pursuant to an award in a compensation order
column3: of compensation from his employer for injuries incurred in the course of employment

column1: shall operate as an assignment to the employer of all right of the person entitled to compensation to recover damages against [a person other than the employer] unless [the longshoreman] shall commence an action against such third person within six months after such award.""

column2: who had been injured aboard ship in the course of their employment
column3: accepted compensation under such an award from their respective stevedore employers.  More than six months after the awards
column4: each petitioner commenced an action in Federal District Court against the shipowner involved
column5: alleging that the shipowner had negligently caused his injury.  The District Courts granted summary judgments for the shipowners (respondents) on the ground that
column6: because petitioners failed to bring suit within six months of the compensation awards
column7: their causes of action had been assigned to their employers
column8: who thereafter had the exclusive right to pursue the third-party claims.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  Section 33(b) precludes petitioners from pursuing their third-party claims against respondent shipowners.  Pp.  451 U. S. 602-618.

(a) The language of  33(b) is both mandatory and unequivocal.  The only conditions precedent to the statutory assignment are the acceptance of compensation pursuant to an award in a compensation order and the passage of the required 6-month period
column2: both of which conditions were satisfied in these eases.  When such assignment occurs
column3: it transfers to the employer the employee's entire right to commence a third-party action
column4: the words ""all right"" in  33(b) precluding the possibility of only a partial assignment or concurrent rights in the employee and employer to sue in the postassignment period.  Although

column1: petitioners' employers failed to pursue the assigned claims
column2: the statute does not expressly require that they do so
column3: nor does it provide for relief to employees should the assigned claims lie dormant.  Pp.  451 U. S. 602-604.

column1: (b) Nothing in the legislative history shows any intent by Congress to preserve the employee's right to commence a third-party suit after the 6-month period expires.  To the contrary
column2: the history indicates that once that period expires
column3: the employer possesses complete control of third-party claims.  Moreover
column4: the history forecloses the argument that Congress did not intend an assignment of a third-party claim to be effective unless there was an absence of any potential conflict of interest between the assignee and the longshoreman.  The simple standard set forth in  33(b) -- exclusive control of the cause of action in the employee for six months and in the employer thereafter -- protects the interests of both employees and employers
column5: and is consistent with the Act's general policy of encouraging the prompt and efficient administration of compensation claims.  Pp.  451 U. S. 604-612.

column1: (c) There is no evidence that Congress gave the employee the right or procedural mechanism
column2: after assignment
column3: to compel the assignee either to bring a third-party suit or to reassign the cause of action to the employee in response to a formal request to do so.  And Congress' failure to amend  33(b) in 1972
column4: when the Act was thoroughly reexamined
column5: does not evidence congressional approval of a Court of Appeals' decision holding that
column6: notwithstanding  33(b)
column7: a longshoreman who has accepted compensation under an award may maintain a third-party action whenever it becomes evident that his employer has no intention to file suit on the assigned claim.  Such legislative inaction does not modify the plain terms of  33(b).  Pp.  451 U. S. 612-617.

column2: affirmed.  STEVENS
column3: J.
column4: delivered the opinion for a unanimous Court.
